topic: student visa types, application process, documentation, fees, entry rules, OPT, extensions, change of status, and guidance for dependents and Canadian/Bermuda citizens

topic.title: Applying for Your U.S. Student Visa

resources.canadian_visitors: U.S. Embassy and Consulate websites in Canada

good_to_know.interview_tips: Explain why you want to study in the U.S., how you will support yourself, and your plans after graduation.
good_to_know.entry_restrictions: F or M visa students cannot enter earlier than 30 days before program start; early entry requires B visa and change of status.
good_to_know.new_students: F and M visas can be issued up to 365 days before the course starts. Entry allowed no more than 30 days before start date.
good_to_know.continuing_students: Visas may be issued anytime if enrolled at a SEVP-approved school and in SEVIS. Entry allowed anytime before classes start.
good_to_know.canada_bermuda: Citizens generally do not require a visa but must present a valid Form I-20 at admission

fees.instructions: Check the U.S. Embassy/Consulate website for details on fee payment

required_documents: Valid passport (at least 6 months beyond stay unless exempt)
Application fee receipt if prepayment required
Photo (uploaded to DS-160 or printed if upload fails)
Form I-20 (signed by student and school official, issued via SEVIS)
Separate Form I-20 for spouse/minor children if accompanying
additional_documents_may_include: Standardized test scores required by U.S. school
Proof of intent to depart after studies
Proof of funding for tuition, living, and travel costs

visa_interview.purpose: Determine qualification for student visa under U.S. law
visa_interview.fingerprints: Ink-free digital scans usually taken during interview
visa_interview.administrative_processing: May be required; consular officer will inform
visa_interview.post_approval: May require issuance fee payment and passport/visa return arrangements
visa_interview.fraud_warning: Misrepresentation or fraud may result in permanent visa refusal or denial of entry

entry_to_us.note: Visa does not guarantee entry; DHS/CBP officials at port-of-entry decide
entry_to_us.admission: CBP official provides stamp or Form I-94
entry_to_us.procedures: Check CBP website for arrival procedures, restricted/prohibited items
entry_to_us.b_visa_option: Students may enter early on B visa and apply for change of status to F or M; may also depart and re-enter on student visa

optional_practical_training.description: Temporary employment directly related to F-1 student's area of study

extending_stay.f_visa_departure: Must leave within 60 days after program end date (including authorized training)
extending_stay.extension: Request through USCIS. Check SEVP website for maintaining status
extending_stay.consequence_of_overstay: Visa voided, future visa eligibility may be affected

change_of_status.possibility: May request change in nonimmigrant status through USCIS while in the U.S.
change_of_status.note: Change of status does not require a new visa; new visa needed upon departure

additional_information.visa_guarantee: No guarantee of visa issuance. Do not make final travel plans without a visa.
additional_information.working_in_us: See Students and Employment and Form I-765 instructions on USCIS website
additional_information.temporary_absences: Check SEVP for guidance on returning students

spouse_children.schooling: Minor children can attend U.S. school
spouse_children.same_sex_spouses: Adjudicated same as opposite sex spouses

additional_information.expired_passport: Valid visa in expired passport remains valid unless canceled/revoked; use with new passport for travel
